physDesc.p: The letter consists of two sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides. The top of each new sheet (every other page) has a page number typed in the center. There are two holes punched at the top of each page, though only one is in the center of the sheet and the other is cut off by the side of the paper, only leaving a half circle cut out. There are a few places where words are crossed out and replaced with penciled-in words.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: This is the post-script of the letter I sent you yesterday. The advertisement did not get in, and I am enclosing it.

Your letter, containing the Stevens [sic] slam in “The New Age” on Ezra, came in this morning. I do not know what to say. Ezra undoubtedly deserved the feeling, but I do not think anything deserves that expression. Our whole literary manners over here are so different. No paper would print such a diatribe. I do not think anybody would think of writing it. Anyone who did would dish himself for ever. But I am awfully glad you sent it, as it shows the way the wind is blowing. It also opens my eyes to many things: in the first place to Ezra’s methods, which have done him such an incalculable amount of harm this side of the ocean and which, living in an atmosphere of recriminations, seemed quite the thing to him to do; in the second place, to your letter to Croly which however right in substance, was couched in terms which we do not use in business over here. I say all this, not by way of criticism, but merely to give you an idea of how different the customs of the two countries are. They are clearly different places, when you come to think of it.

I have a review of Fletcher’s book in “The New Republic,” and they very kindly asked a man to review the Anthology whom Greenslet suggested. I have very little hopes of getting any intelligent reviews, however, over here. Nobody seems to know such about the business. A man named Floyd Dell, who sometimes writes for “The Little Review,” came out in “The New Republic” to-day in a review of Fletcher’s Ficke’s book and incidentally spoke of the parlour fire-works of the Imagists. I am answering this in a letter to “The New Republic,” showing that we who have split off are broad and vital and not all the “precieux” folk they take us for. My hands are positively sore with the wires I have pulled to get us noticed intelligently. But I think we shall do pretty well.

“Spoon River” is the whole shooting match over here at the moment, but it is a good book of its kind, its kind being character drawing and the picture of a place, but hardly poetry to my mind. I am sending you a copy, in case you have not got one. But patience, patience! We shall win over them all in the end, I am sure. Rome was not built in a day, and artistic reputations that amount to anything do not spring up over night.

I have sent three copies of the book each to Lawrence and Flint. Hilda, I suppose, will go in with yours. If Sadler won’t give you as many as you must over there, just write to me and I will send you any amount. You see, it is my edition over here, and I can do what I please with it. The account won’t come in until July. Whatever is paid I shall divide into six equal parts, keeping one myself and sending the rest round. One-sixth of the sale of a book like this won’t be very brilliant, so do not expect much. It will probably be only postage stamps.
Fletcher is still here. I have sent him in your letter. I do wish I could see you and Hilda and have a long, good talk. Writing does not take the place.

note.p: James Stephens (1880-1950), Irish novelist and poet. His letter to the editor in March 18, 1915 issue of The New Age, Vol. 16, No. (March 18, 1915) responds to a column by Ezra Pound in the February 25, 1915 issue (Vol. 16, No. 17) titled “The Non-Existence of Ireland” (451-453), about his impatience with sentimentality in contemporary writing about Ireland, arguing that only in the prose of James Joyce does he find an aesthetically satisfying and believable version of Ireland. Stephens is mentioned in passing as “a mild enough writer [who] has chosen a life in Paris.” Stephen’s letter expounds at length on his complaints against Pound:

quote.p: There are so many things I wish he would do: I wish he would not mention my name; I wish he would not write quite so mistakenly about Synge; I wish he would not write quite so mistakenly about Mr. Lawrence; I wish he would not write quite so mistakenly about Mr. Joyce; I wish he could believe that we knew all about Mr. Joyce’s work long before he did, and that we still prefer Mr. Joyce’s verse to his prose . . . I wish he would not say that I ran away from Ireland; I wish he would run back to America; I wish he had never run away from that great country; I wish he would bury himself and stay buried. . . I have written Mr. Pound’s name. I am going to fumigate my pen. (551).

note.p: Stephens concludes with a short poem in doggerel that ends “And God who made all things has made the world and made it round, / And He made policemen’s feet to beat in the verse of Ezra Pound” (551).

div.note: Floyd Dell, "On Behalf of a Book of Poems," The New Republic, April 24, 1915, pp. 309-310. In this review of Arthur Davison Ficke's The Man on the Hilltop and Other Poems (New York: Mitchell Kennerly, 1915) Dell describe's Ficke's book of sonnets as "modern in content," if not in form, arguing that "the endeavour to acheive in verse some of the effects which have recently been left to the prose novel . . . seems to me more daring, more difficult, more exciting than the parlor fireworks of the Imagists" (310).
